awd_titl_txt: MRI:  Acquisition of a Laser Scanning Microscope with Multi-spectral Imaging and Super-resolution
awd_abstract_narration:
An award is made to the University of Hawaii at Manoa (UHM) to acquire a new laser scanning microscope (LSM) with multi-spectral imaging and super-resolution capabilities to support research and training in the life sciences. The LSM will be used for demonstrations for K-12 science classes of local public and private schools, as part of laboratory demonstrations and sessions for undergraduate and graduate university courses in the life sciences, participants in NSF REU programs and in other specialty workshops, and by undergraduate and graduate students and postdoctoral associates conducting research with UHM faculty. Attracting youth to careers in the sciences and training the next generation of scientists, engineers and educators in advanced techniques are major goals of our facility and this institution.

The requested LSM will be used by researchers to answer fundamental questions in cell biology, developmental biology, ecology, marine biology, microbiology, oceanography, symbiosis and tropical agriculture. The new instrument will support NSF- and other funded research in a broad range of life sciences including: marine invertebrate-bacterial symbiosis; structure and function of marine bacterial communities; plant-fungal symbioses; crustacean peptide hormones; protein expression and enzyme function in a model plant; bacterial biofilms in marine larval settling; amphibian-microbe-fungal associations; and marine copepod population structure.  The results from these studies will be published in scientific peer-reviewed journals, presented at scientific meetings, and used in both teaching and public outreach activities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The overall goal of this project was to acquire a laser scanning microscope with multi-spectral imaging and super-resolution capabilities to support research and training in the life sciences at the University of Hawaiʻi at Mānoa (UHM) in Honolulu, Hawaiʻi.  After careful review of available instruments, we acquired a Leica SP8 X confocal system with White Light Laser, Lightning Super-resolution and FALCON FLIM on a Leica DM6 Upright Microscope. The new instrument brought new imaging techniques not previously available at UHM including FRAP, FLIM, FLIM-FRET, adaptive deconvolution and other types of spectral analysis.

Intellectual Merit:  The Leica confocal system was used by researchers to answer fundamental questions in cell biology, developmental biology, ecology, marine biology, microbiology, symbiosis and tropical agriculture. The new instrument supported NSF- and other funded research in a broad range of life sciences. The images and other data obtained on the Leica SP8 X confocal system have improved our understanding in the following areas: development and persistence of a squid-bacterial symbiosis over its daily and extended life cycle; protein-protein interactions associated with thermotolerance in plant protoplasts; pattern of oogenesis in female copepods emerging from diapause in sub-arctic waters; morphology of feeding structures in a copepod parasite of rays; anatomy of visual and bioluminescent structures in marine crustacea and terrestrial arachnids; examination of grazing ecology of a mixotrophic marine flagellate; investigations of vertical transmission of obligate bacterial symbionts in a coffee berry borer beetle; development and laterality of the sensory system in sighted and blind cavefish; and validation of an instrument developed to search for evidence of life in extraterrestrial materials.

The new Leica confocal is housed in the Biological Electron Microscope Facility which moved to newly built quarters in the Life Sciences Building designed to our specifications in August 2020. The new facility has much better temperature, humidity, and lighting control than the old location.  The Leica confocal complements the other microscopes in the facility including scanning and transmission electron microscopes, an older confocal microscope and other fluorescence and brightfield systems.

Broader Impacts:  Over 50 users were trained to operate the confocal microscope independently including 13 faculty, 7 technical staff, 5 postdoctoral researchers, 17 graduate students, 6 undergraduate students and 2 non-UHM researchers. Of the 28 trainees, 71% were female.  An additional 250 undergraduate and graduate students and participants in a REU program were introduced to the Leica confocal and its capabilities as part of laboratory tours and other workshops. The UHM student body is ethnically diverse and our users reflect that diversity. The results of the research conducted using the microscope have been disseminated in local and national scientific symposia, in master’s theses and doctoral dissertations and in peer-reviewed journal articles.

The Covid-19 pandemic and its associated work-at-home orders, transition to online teaching and social distancing requirements has and continues to be a problem for expanding the individual user base and for incorporating the instrument in more STEM courses. We continue to work on with ways to minimize the negative consequences of the pandemic.
